p: The Japan triple disaster, on March 11, 2011 in which an earthquake, tsunami, and a meltdown at a nuclear power plant represented a severe natural disaster [ 24]. A study assessing health risk behaviors following the event identified a significant increase in alcohol use following the disaster [ 25]. In this study out of 37,867 individuals who did not drink prior to the Japan triple disaster, 9.6% reported drinking in 2012, and 53.8% reported continued drinking in 2013 [ 25]. This is an example of health risk behaviors that may be long lasting following a crisis. Similar to decreased sleep, increased alcohol use over time can have deleterious effects on the mind and body.
